newsitem.title: USA: US corp bond secondary trade quiet,new issues eyed.
newsitem.headline: US corp bond secondary trade quiet,new issues eyed.

text.p: U.S. corporate high-grade secondary activity experienced yet another quiet session as players focused on the slew of new issues hitting the market, dealers said.
Spreads to U.S. Treasuries were seen unchanged across most maturities, they added.
"It's been very quiet with not much two-way flow seen, however, retail has been pretty active," one trader said.
Turning to the primary arena, a slew of new corporate debt deals hit the market as issuers capitalized on attractive interest rates to wrap up year-end financing, dealers said.

Deutsche Bank Financial Inc, a unit of Deutsche Bank AG, issued $1.1 billion in 6.70 percent subordinated 10-year notes to yield 54 basis points over Treasuries via lead mananger Deutsche Morgan Grenfell.
The size of the offering was increased, from an initial $1.0 billion, to meet investor demand, the lead manager said.
"Deutsche's deal was posted all sold and is currently being agressively bid for on the street," one trader said.
Also, Nike Inc set $200 million in 6.375 percent seven-year notes to yield 34 basis points over Treasuries via joint managers Goldman Sachs and Salomon Brothers.
The Nike deal was also upped in size, from an initially expected amount of $150 million, to meet investor demand, syndicate sources said.
Another $360 million was issued by the National Power Corp of Philippines (NAPOCOR) in a two-part debt offering via Salomon Brothers.
The first tranche, $200 million in 10-year 7.875 percent guaranteed bonds, were priced to yield 167 basis points over U.S. Treasuries.
The second tranche, $160 million in 8.40 percent 20-year bonds, were priced to yield 190 basis points over Treasuries.
Among other issues priced on Tuesday were Consolidated Natural Gas' $150 million in 6.625 percent notes, which were priced to yield 43 basis points over Treasuries.
Still, dealers said more deals are on the horizon as we approach the end to the calendar year.
"The potential for more more issuance is there...deals are currently being worked on as we speak," said one high-grade syndicate source.
Among upcoming debt offerings are Crown Cork & Seal's $1.2 billion debt offering via Salomon Brothers and Philip Morris' $500 million debt offering via Goldman Sachs.
Turning to the high-yield sector, prices were seen trading up by 1/8 to a 1/4 point in light volume as players focused on media and telecom paper, dealers said.
CAI Wireless Systems Inc debt continued on its decline of the last few days and was seen bid at 46 with a 50 offer, traders said.
On Monday, the paper was quoted at a 50 bid, 55 offer continuing a slide that began on Friday when the debt was hit the hardest.
On Friday, the paper dropped more than 20 points after news that Bell Atlantic Corp and NYNEX Corp might reevaluate the method they use in getting video to homes.
The regional Bells have $100 million invested in CAI.
People's Choice TV debt was unchanged from Monday's levels of 34 bid, 36 offer, gaining two points from its initial 10 point drop on Friday, traders said.
CS Wireless was seen trading at a 32 bid, 35 offer, traders added.
Among new secondary issues, Colt Telecom's new issue was seen trading at a 57-1/2 bid, traders said.
--Nancy Leinfuss, 212-859-1675
